content: jumper has a little waist compared to paddy red jumper so i have decreased more rounds for him see step 14a swatch stitch and checklist i recommend making a 10 cm by 10 cm gauge swatch this will allow you to transfer cm to stitch counts and help you choose the stitch for your jumper the double_crochet stitch will create a more open fabric whereas the half_double_crochet is slightly more dense □ measure your dog and fill in the table above □ choose your stitch double_crochet or half_double_crochet or something more exciting □ make 10 cm x 10 cm swatch making the jumper the basic jumper is made up from three sections the neck the main body and the jumper flap in section 4 there are a few finishing touches including the leg straps which are great for keeping the jumper flap down for sections 2 and 3 you can choose which stitch to use for simplicity i have used double_crochet in this guide throughout section 1 neck 🄰 1 using the smaller hook and the contrast colour make a chain the length of 2 single_crochet in the back bump of the second chain from the hook and continue making 1 single_crochet in each back bump 3 turn chain 1 single_crochet in the bl of each stitch 🄱 4 repeat r2 until the piece will slightly stretch to the length of 5 join the last row to the first to make the collar a you can just use a slip_stitch join b or i found this to create a less visible join and maintain the ribbed pattern by - insert hook through bl - insert hook through the fl of the st you are joining to - pull up a loop - pull through all three loops on the hook - continue for each st across cut yarn and sew in ends section 2 middle section 6 using the larger hook and the main colour turn the piece and work 1 single_crochet into the end of each row 7 turn chain 2 a at this point you will begin making the main stitch you have chosen half_double_crochet or double_crochet recommended for this guide i will continue using double_crochet b you will use the next two four row to increase the garment 🄲 circumference to increase the stitches at regular intervals 🄲 measure how big the piece currently is take this away from to calculate how many cm you need to increase by you can then check on your swatch how many stitches you need to add c at the end of each row join the last stitch to the first with a tight slip_stitch and remember to turn and chain 2 at the beginning of every new row 8 try the jumper on your pup be warned this might take a few goes to get right you will probably need to increase less than you first think 9 make plain rounds remembering to turn your work at the end of
